A B S T R A C T

Labdane diterpenes (LDs), and especially sclareol, are important feedstocks for the pharmaceutical and cosmetic industries, and therefore several lines of research have led to their heterologous production in non-photosynthetic microbes and higher plants. The potential of microalgae as bioreactors of natural products has been established for a variety of bioactive metabolites, including terpenes. In this work, a codon optimized sequence encoding a key plant labdane-type diterpene (LD) cyclase, copal-8-ol diphosphate synthase from
Cistus creticus ( CcCLS )
, was introduced into the chloroplast genome of
Chlamydomonas reinhardtii.
Of 49 transplastomic algal lines, 12 produced variable amounts of four LD compounds, namely ent -manoyl oxide, sclareol, labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol and ent -13- epi -manoyl oxide. The total LD concentrations measured in the transplastomic lines reached 1.172 ± 0.05 μg/mg cell DW for the highest overall producer, while the highest yield for sclareol was 0.038 ± 0.001 μg/mg cell DW. Thus, transplastomic expression of a key plant labdane diterpene cyclase in the
C. reinhardtii
chloroplast genome enabled the production of important plant-specific LD compounds.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
Terpenoids constitute the largest group of natural products in both microalgae and plants, among which C 20 diterpenes have the most important pharmacological functions (
; Pattanaik and Lindberg, 2015; Tholl, 2015). A rich source of plant diterpenes is
Cistus creticus
L. ( Cistaceae ), an angiosperm species native to the Greek island of Crete , that carries glands on its leaves secreting a resin consisting mainly of terpenoids, including labdane-type diterpenoids (LDs), which have significant antimicrobial and cytotoxic activities (
). Due to their cosmetic and pharmacological applications, pathway discovery and genetic engineering of LD biosynthetic pathways has gained much attention. The first plant

C. creticus ( Falara et al., 2010 )
. Copal-8-ol diphosphate synthase (CLS) is a type II diterpene synthase (diTPS) that catalyzes the biosynthesis of copal-8-ol diphosphate from geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GGDP). The product of the reaction is a key intermediate metabolite that can be further cyclized to ent -manoyl-oxide, ent -13- epi -manoyl-oxide, labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol and labda-14-ene-8,13-diol (sclareol) (
;
; Sallaud et al., 2012; Schalk et al., 2012) ( Fig. 1 ). Homologs of the enzyme from
Nicotiana tabacum
L. ( Solanaceae ) (Sallaud et al., 2012) and from
Salvia sclarea
L. ( Lamiaceae ) (
; Schalk et al., 2012) have been functionally characterized and shown to be involved in the synthesis of ( Z )-labda-12,14-dien-8-ol ( Z -abienol) and sclareol, respectively. Sclareol, a LD isolated originally from clary sage (
Salvia sclarea
), is an essential feedstock for the fine chemicals industry, where it is used for the production of a semisynthetic substitute of ambergris, a highly prized fragrance produced by the intestinal tract of the sperm whale (
). In
S. sclarea ,
the production of sclareol involves the action of two enzymes, a class II enzyme (CLS) and a class I sclareol synthase (
; Schalk et al., 2012), a case that apparently differs from that of
C. creticus ,
where extensive RNA-seq of isolated trichomes and fruit was unable to detect any class I labdane-type diterpene synthase genes, while it detected additional class II enzymes (unpublished data) ( Fig. 1 ).

The key role played by CLS in the biosynthesis of several LD compounds makes it an attractive target for metabolic engineering. In this work, chloroplast transformation of
C. reinhardtii
was performed with a codon optimized version of the
C. creticus
copal-8-ol diphosphate synthase (CO-CcCLS). The final products of this manipulation were entmanoyl oxide, sclareol, labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol and ent -13- epi -manoyl oxide.

sec.title: 2.2. Screening of homoplasmic lines by GC-MS analysis
sec.p:
To verify the functionality of CO-CcCLS introduced into the
C. reinhardtii
chloroplast, an initial screening of the 49 homoplasmic lines grown in photomixotrophic conditions was performed for detecting semi-volatile labdane diterpene (LD) metabolites by GC-MS. Retention time and mass spectra were tested against an authentic standard of manoyl oxide C 13 epimers mixture, from which product 1a was identified as ent -manoyl oxide and 1b was ent -13- epi -manoyl oxide (Supplementary Fig. 2 ). In 12 out of 49 lines (CLS1, CLS2, CLS4, CLS5, CLS6, CLS8, CLS9, CLS10, CLS11, CLS13, CLS14 and CLS38), hereinafter referred to as CLS-OX lines, the two products were clearly detectable.

For better detection and quantification, a more sensitive GC-MS analytical method was set up in Selected Ion Monitoring (SIM) mode and used to screen the CLS-OX lines, enabling the identification of all four LD compounds, namely ent -manoyl-oxide, ent -13- epi -manoyl-oxide, labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol and labda-14-ene-8,13-diol (sclareol).

Fig. 3 shows, as an example, the GC-MS chromatograms of the
Chlamydomonas
wild type cw15 strain (CrWT), of transformant CLS9 and of
C. creticus
resin. Concentrations of produced LDs were expressed in μg/ mg microalgae cells dry weight (Fig. 4, Supplementary Table 1), using a sclareol authentic standard calibration curve (Supplementary Fig. 3 ). In all CLS-OX lines, the highest yield (0.115–1.082 μg/mg DW) was obtained for ent -manoyl oxide, followed by sclareol (0.024–0.038 μg/mg DW), labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol (0.022–0.036 μg/mg DW) and e nt -13- epi - manoyl oxide (0.021–0.026 μg/mg DW) (Fig. 4, Supplementary Table 1). Line CLS38 was the highest producer of total LDs (1.172 ± 0.05 μg/mg DW) while line CLS9 was the highest sclareol producer (0.038 ± 0.001 μg/mg DW) (Fig. 4, Supplementary Table 1).

sec.title: 2.3. CO-CcCLS protein accumulation in transplastomic transformants
sec.p: CO-CcCLS protein accumulation in the 12 transplastomic transformants (CLS-OX lines) producing LDs was evaluated by immunoblotting, using total protein extracts and an anti-FLAG monoclonal antibody ( Fig. 5 ). The results clearly illustrate the presence of a specific band with the expected molecular weight (86.9 KDa) only in the pCG2- FLAGCO-CcCLS transformants. Several non-specific bands were present in all transformants, including the ones obtained using the pCG2- FLAG empty vector. The highest protein accumulation was observed in the CLS8 transformant (indicated in red in Fig. 5 ).

sec.title: 2.4. LD accumulation under di ff erent growth conditions
sec.p:
Recombinant yeast cells overexpressing CO-CcCLS show increased production of sclareol when cultured in low pH (
,
). To evaluate the relevance of such manipulation in
C. reinhardii , CLS-OX
line CLS9 was chosen, since it is the highest producer for sclareol and labda-13-ene-8 α , 15 diol. Line CLS9 was cultivated in photomixotrophic conditions at pH 7.0 (the usual pH of the TAP medium) and pH 6.0, the lowest pH compatible with cell growth. Lowering of the pH to 6.0 caused only minor changes in the overall LD composition (Supplementary Fig. 4 ).

sec.title: 3. Discussion
sec.p:
In vitro LD biosynthesis using CcCLS and other plant copal-8-ol diphosphate synthases, followed by dephosphorylation of the product, resulted in the synthesis of labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol as the major product, with trace amounts of ent -manoyl oxide C 13 epimers and sclareol (
;
; Pateraki et al., 2014; Sallaud et al., 2012; Zerbe et al., 2012). Expression of CcCLS in a yeast vector system using a modular approach led to the accumulation, in the culture medium, of labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol in cells grown at neutral pH, and of sclareol in cells grown at pH 3.5–4.5 (
,
). These findings suggest that sclareol is produced through acid hydrolysis in the medium, in the absence of sclareol synthase. In our work, sclareol production was already high at pH 7.0, and was not influenced by the pH of the medium (Supplementary Fig. 4 ). The formation of all four LDs in our transformants is probably due to direct conversion from copal-8-ol diphosphate, the product of CLS enzymatic activity ( Fig. 1 ). It is therefore possible that, in
C. reinhardtii ,
copal-8-ol diphosphate is converted into LDs, including sclareol, through the action of non-specific terpenoid phosphatases. Genetic manipulation of such phosphatases, and/or introduction of genes specifically leading to the production of any of the 4 LDs shown in Fig. 1 , such as CLS coupled with the
S. sclarea
sclareol synthase, may lead to higher levels of sclareol.

Aromatic and medicinal plants are valuable sources of natural products. However, since most of them are not amenable to genetic manipulation, it is difficult to obtain strains producing higher amounts of these compounds. In the present work, we have demonstrated the potential of
C. reinhardtii
to use its biochemical arsenal for producing high levels of bioactive LDs in the absence of metabolic optimization steps. The availability of genome-scale models for
C. reinhardtii
metabolism (
) paves the way for further optimization of the production of these important bioactive compounds.

sec.title: 4. Experimental
sec.p: 4.1. Cloning of CO-CcCLS gene in a vector for chloroplast transformation

The CDS region for the CLS gene, corresponding to the
C. creticus
( Cistaceae ) transcript (accession number HM537017), was codon optimized ( CO-CcCLS ) according to
Chlamydomonas chloroplast
codon usage, using the Optimizer application (http://genomes.urv.es/ OPTIMIZER) as described in
. The CO-CcCLS sequence without the chloroplast transit peptide (Supplementary
4.2. Chlamydomonas strains , transformation and growth conditions

The cell wall-less
C. reinhardtii
strain cw15 was grown on a rotary shaker photomixotrophically in Tris acetate phosphate (TAP), pH 7.0 medium at 25 ̊C at a photoperiod of 16 h light (120 μE m −2 s −1 ) and 8 h dark. For transformation, cells were grown to mid-log phase (concentration of 5 × 10 6 cells/ml, counted using a TC10 automated cell counter (Bio-Rad, California , USA ), and chloroplast transformation was performed as previously described (
).
C. reinhardtii
cells transformed with the empty vector pCG2-FLAG were used as negative controls in all subsequent analyses. Transformants were propagated for 10 rounds in selective TAP agar medium, pH 7.0, supplemented with 100 μg/ml spectinomycin to obtain homoplasmic lines.

sec.title: 4.3. Screening of homoplasmic lines by GC-MS analysis
sec.p:
Screening of
C. reinhardtii
transformants for LD production was performed on 49 homoplasmic lines, grown to a density of 2 × 10 6 cells/ml in 200 ml of liquid TAP medium at pH 7.0, supplemented with 20 μg/ml spectinomycin. Cells were harvested by centrifugation at 3000 g at 4 ̊ C for 10 min and pellets were resuspended in 6 ml of hexane. Extraction was performed by vortexing for 1 min and sonicating in an ultrasonic bath for 2 × 30 min. Samples were then centrifuged at 8000 g for 20 min at room temperature (RT) and the supernatant was collected and concentrated by a Speedvac concentrator to a final volume of 100 μl. One μl of extract was subjected to gas chromatography-mass spectrometry analysis (GC-MS) as previously described (
). GC-MS analysis was performed in scan mode with the apolar MEGA-5 MS column (MEGA, Legnano (MI) Italy ) using a Shimadzu QP-2010 system (SHIMADZU, Kyoto , Japan ) with electronic ionization set at 70 eV. A mixture of ent -manoyl oxide and ent -13- epi -manoyl oxide was used as standard (
). Extracts of
C. reinhardtii
transformed with the empty vector pCG2- FLAG were used as a negative control. To calculate the peak retention index (RI), a mixture of C 9 – C 25 alkanes was used (van Den Dool and Dec. Kratz, 1963). To study the influence of pH on LDs production, pCG2 (containing the empty vector) and CLS9 transformants were grown in 50 ml TAP , pH 7.0, with 20 μg/ml spectinomycin (Sueoka, 1960) for 72 h at 25 ̊ C in continuous light (120 μE m −2 s −1 ), and then diluted 1: 20 in 20 ml of TAP medium at pH 6.0 and pH 7.0 (two biological replications for each transformant). After 96 h, cells were collected by centrifugation at 3000 g at 4 ̊ C for 10 min and the pellets were processed as described in section 4.5.

sec.title: 4.4. Protein extraction and immunoblotting
sec.p:
To verify correct expression of the CO-CcCLS protein in
Chlamydomonas
, protein blot analysis was performed on the 12 transformants accumulating the highest LD levels. The transformants were grown in the same conditions described above at pH 7.0. Total protein was extracted from 6 × 10 6 cells by directly re-suspending the cell pellets in 50 μl of SDS-loading buffer (10% glycerol, 50 mM Tris-HCl pH 6.8, 0.1% bromophenol blue, 2% SDS, 2.5% 2-mercaptoethanol). Samples were then boiled for 10 min, centrifuged at 18,000 g for 30 min at RT and 5 μl of the supernatant were subjected to 10% SDS-PAGE in a Mini Protean apparatus (Bio-Rad, California , USA ). Proteins were subsequently transferred onto a PVDF membrane (GE Healthcare, USA ) using the Trans-Blot Turbo system (Bio-Rad, California , USA ). After blocking overnight at 4 ̊ C with 5% non-fat dry milk in PBS (20 mM Na 2 HPO 4 , 2 mM NaH 2 PO 4 150 mM NaCl; pH 7.2), membranes were incubated for 2 h at RT with a 1:2000 dilution of a monoclonal antiFLAG antibody M2-Peroxidase (Sigma-Aldrich, Germany ). The bound antibody was revealed using the ECL Plus system “Enhanced ChemiLuminescence” (GE Healthcare, USA ) and detected by luminometry with a Chemidoc ImageLab system with ImageLab 4.0 software (Bio-Rad, California , USA ).

sec.title: 4.5. GC-MS analysis of transplastomic transformants
sec.p:
The 12 transformants accumulating the highest LD levels (CLS-OX) were further characterized by using a GC coupled to a triple quadrupole MS (GC-TQMS TSQ8000 (ThermoFisher Scientific, MA, USA ), operating in electron ionization. Briefly, these transformants were grown in 25 ml TAP , pH 7.0, with 20 μg/ml spectinomycin, subsequently pelleted at 3000 g for 10 min at 4 ̊ C and re-suspended by vortexing in 700 μl 10 mM Tris-HCl, 1 mM EDTA (TE), pH 8.0. Cells were then lysed by sonication on ice at 10 Hz output (10 s each) for 3 times and 700 μl of hexane was added. Next, samples were centrifuged at 8000 g for 20 min at 4 ̊ C , the supernatant collected, dried in a concentrator and resuspended in 20 μl of hexane. One μl was injected using a TriPlus RSH autosampler (Thermofisher Scientific, MA, USA ), and semi-volatile metabolites, including labdane diterpenes, were separated using a Thermo TG-SQC column ( 15m × 0.25 mm x 0.25 μm), with helium as carrier gas at a constant flow of 1.2 mL/min. Oven temperature conditions were: 40 ̊ C for 1 min, 20 ̊ C /min ramp until 120 ̊ C and 10 ̊ C / min until 250 ̊ C , which was held for 5 min. Mass spectra (MS) were recorded in scan mode in the 45–450 m /z range, and in Selected Ion Monitoring mode using typical transitions for the 4 labdane diterpenes (m/z 257, 272, 275, 290 and 308). MS transfer line temperature and Ion Source temperature were set at 240 ̊ C and 250 ̊ C , respectively. Chromatograms and spectra were recorded and analyzed using the Excalibur software (Thermofisher Scientific, MA, USA ). All solvents used were LC-MS grade (Merck Millipore, MA, USA ). Labdane diterpenes were unequivocally identified by comparing mass spectra and retention times with authentic standards (
) and by interrogation of the NIST 17 mass spectral library. For quantifying the concentrations of the 4 LDs in each transplastomic line, a calibration curve was constructed with a commercial sclareol standard (Sigma-Aldrich, Germany , Cat. No. 49944), using 3 replicates per point (Supplementary Fig. 2 ). Sclareol calibration curve data were interpolated with LD signal intensities of each microalgal line, and metabolite quantification was performed using peak areas normalized by the microalgal dry weight.
